verses.text: If I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but do not have love, I have become sounding brass or a clanging cymbal.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes that supernatural gifts like speaking in tongues are empty without genuine love. The reference to 'tongues of men and of angels' stresses eloquence and spiritual gifts but insists on love as the true mark of the Christian. Note the spiritual interpretation: spiritual gifts serve the Church only when motivated by love.

verses.text: And if I have prophecy, and understand all mysteries and all knowledge; and if I have all faith, so as to move mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing.
verses.comment: Knowledge, faith, and prophecy are highly valued in the church, yet Paul makes clear that their highest purpose is fulfilled only in love. Moving mountains is hyperbolic, echoing Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 17:20, but the ultimate measure is love. This points to the necessity of charity as the foundation of Christian life and ministry.

verses.text: If I give away all I possess, and if I deliver my body to be burned, but do not have love, I gain nothing.
verses.comment: Even the greatest acts of self-sacrifice, including martyrdom, are empty without love. This shows that the motivation behind good works is as important as the acts themselves. Genuine, self-giving love fulfills the commandments and is the summit of Christian life.

verses.text: Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not arrogant.
verses.comment: Paul gives a vivid description of the character of love, mirroring the fruits of the Spirit (see Galatians 5:22). This standard calls all believers to imitate Christ, who is the perfect model of patience and kindness. The Church’s unity is preserved by living out this kind of love.

verses.text: It does not behave indecently, is not self-seeking, is not easily angered, keeps no record of wrongs.
verses.comment: Paul continues describing the qualities of true love, which mirror the character of Christ. The Christian is called to seek the good of others above oneself and to practice real forgiveness, as Christ instructs in Matthew 18.

verses.text: Love does not rejoice in unrighteousness, but rejoices with the truth.
verses.comment: Genuine love never delights in evil, but stands with the truth. This reveals a spiritual dimension, where love and truth are inseparable. Authentic Christian love upholds doctrinal truth and moral goodness together.

verses.text: It bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
verses.comment: Loving as Christ commands means unconditional perseverance. 'Believes all things' refers to the trust and confidence love places in God and each other, not gullibility. 'Endures all things' hints at suffering for the sake of unity and for others, following Jesus’ own sacrificial example.

verses.text: Love never fails. But if there are prophecies, they will cease; if tongues, they will be stilled; if knowledge, it will pass away.
verses.comment: Every spiritual gift is temporary and will come to an end with the coming perfection, but love is eternal. Paul subtly tells us to pursue what lasts forever over what is only for this present age. Love is the highest virtue and foundation for Christian maturity.

verses.text: For we know in part and we prophesy in part;
verses.comment: This verse teaches human limitation in understanding God’s truth in this life. Spiritual gifts reveal only a portion of God's fullness; one day, this partial knowledge will give way to perfect understanding.

verses.text: but when the perfect comes, the partial will pass away.
verses.comment: 'The perfect' refers to the final fulfillment at Christ’s return, when believers will see God face to face and lack nothing. Here, there is also a spiritual sense pointing to the fullness of Christian maturity and unity through the grace of God.

verses.text: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, thought like a child, reasoned like a child. But when I became a man, I put away childish things.
verses.comment: Paul uses growing from childhood to adulthood as a metaphor for spiritual maturity. The Christian life is a journey of growth into the maturity that reflects Christ. With the coming of the perfect, believers will leave behind all inadequate understanding.

verses.text: For now we see only a reflection in a mirror, but then face to face. Now I know in part; but then I will know fully, just as I also have been fully known.
verses.comment: Earthly knowledge is indirect and incomplete; the future promise is perfect communion with God—'face to face.' This mirrors Moses’ special relationship with God in Num 12:8 and anticipates believers’ ultimate union with God in eternity.

verses.text: And now these three remain: faith, hope, and love. But the greatest of these is love.
verses.comment: Paul concludes the chapter with, faith, hope, and love as the essential marks of the Christian life, with love as supreme. Love will endure forever. This reflects the central virtue and goal of Christian unity and life—being united in love, which is the fullness of Christ’s teaching.
